treatment.reference: Thermococcus aegaeicus sp. nov. and Staphylothermus hellenicus sp. nov., two novel hyperthermophilic archaea isolated from geothermally heated vents off Palaeochori Bay, Milos, Greece IJSEM 50:2101-2108
treatment.description: Cells are irregular cocci with a diameter of 0.8-1.5 µm. Cells occasionally form aggregates of up to ten cells. Growth occurs between 50 and 95 °C with an optimum between 88 and 90 °C. Doubling time at 90 °C is 1.1 h. pH range of growth is between 4.5 and 7.5 with an optimum around pH 6. Optimal NaCl concentration is 2%, but growth is observed between 0.5 and 6.5%. Obligate anaerobe, utilizing complex organic compounds like yeast extract, peptone and tryptone as carbon source. Obligate heterotroph. Starch can be utilized under an N2/CO2 atmosphere but not under an H2/CO2 atmosphere. No growth on pyruvate, malt extract, maltose and casein. Elemental sulfur stimulates growth. DNA G+C content is 45 mol%. The type strain was isolated from sediments of Palaeochori Bay, Milos, Greece, located at a depth of 4 m. The type strain is P5T (=DSM 12767T=JCM 10828T). Non-motile. Unable to grow in the presence of casein, chitin, pyruvate, cellulose, sodium formate, maltose, glucose, cellobiose, trehalose, ribose, sorbose, sucrose or methanol as sole carbon sources under H2/CO2 or N2/CO2. Could not use thiosulfate, sulfite, or sulfate in place of sulfur. G+C content of 45.5 mol%.
